docs.lead_paragraph: The taxi came barreling up Third Avenue late on a damp October night. As the driver tried to bear left, the cab skidded onto a traffic island, slamming into Edward Shalala, who was waiting to cross the street. He was hurled onto the pavement, his face a bloody mess and his right leg shattered, as his surgeon put it, ''like cornflakes.'' In five operations since the 1992 accident, doctors put Mr. Shalala, a 48-year-old artist, back together well enough that he can hobble around on crutches. And last year a jury tried to make him whole financially with a $3.2 million award for damages. But it was mostly an empty promise.

headline.main: Taxi Owners Deftly Dodge Claims of Accident Victims

docs.abstract: Taxicab industry in New York City deftly manuevers to protect itself from big awards to accident victims, even as its cabs hurt more and more people; interviews and probe of dozens of suits show cab companies are among most recalcitrant businesses in paying accident claims; Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani is now roiling industry with proposal to clamp down on dangerous drivers and make it easier for injured people to collect; most of city's cabs and car-service vehicles carry minimal liability insurance and have devised ways to shield assets, including costly taxi medallions, from claims; graphs; photos (L)

byline.original: By CHRISTOPHER DREW and ANDY NEWMAN

docs.lead_paragraph: The County Office for the Aging is looking for volunteers to help seniors fight fraud, abuse and waste in the Medicare-Medicaid system. ''Operation Restore Trust is designed to help seniors identify suspicious and possibly fraudulent billing from medical providers,'' County Executive Andrew J. Spano said.
docs.abstract: Westchester County (NY) Office for Aging seeks volunteers to help seniors fight Medicare and Medicaid fraud, abuse and waste (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Lincoln National Corporation said today that it had agreed to pay Aetna Inc. $1 billion for its United States individual life insurance business. The move is Lincoln's second such acquisition in less than a year, as insurers and other financial companies merge at a record pace in a competition for the retirement dollars of baby boomers.

headline.main: Insurer Buys Unit of Aetna For $1 Billion

docs.abstract: Lincoln National Corp agrees to pay Aetna Inc $1 billion for its US individual life insurance business; Lincoln National, nation's 10th-largest United States life insurer, plans to merge Aetna unit with its Hartford, Conn-based life insurance business, and reduce its payrolls by attrition (S)
